title: HOW TO SETUP A WORM FARM + WHAT TO FEED WORMS | Vermicomposting | Hey It's A Good Life

tasks.task: Set up a worm farm or bin
subtasks: Collect necessary materials (cardboard, browns, bedding, grit, worms, greens, amendments)
Prepare bedding by layering cardboard to prevent worms from escaping
Add brown material (shredded cardboard, newspaper, packing paper, or leaves)
Include compost as a source of organic material and boost microbiome
Introduce worms and provide grit for digestion
Cover worms with a mix of soil and compost for comfort and sun protection
Add food scraps as a starting food source, considering worms' preferences
Monitor moisture levels and maintain proper humidity (similar to a wrung-out sponge)
Address potential pests (e.g., fruit flies) by adding browns, reducing moisture, and using traps
Offer tips and pro advice for successful worm bin setup
Invite viewers to subscribe, like, and comment
Promote additional resources (e.g., eBook for detailed guidance)

Incorporate compost and soil for a hospitable environment

Create escape barrier with newspaper/cardboard to prevent worms from escaping
Add shredded leaves/paper as bedding material
Introduce compost and soil to create a suitable environment for the worms
Include grit (coffee grounds, eggshells, vermiculite) to aid digestion
Feed the worms with preferred food scraps (bananas, apple cores, broccoli)
Cover the food scraps with bedding to minimize pests and maintain hygiene
Monitor the bin's moisture levels to maintain optimal conditions

tasks.task: Set up a worm composting bin
Set up a worm bin for composting

subtasks: Lay down newspaper or cardboard to prevent worms from escaping
Add brown materials (e.g., shredded paper) as bedding layer
Mix in compost and soil to enrich the bedding
Add grit (e.g., coffee grounds, eggshells) for digestion aid
Feed the worms with preferred food scraps (e.g., bananas, apple cores)
Cover food scraps with bedding to minimize pests and maintain hygiene
Monitor moisture levels during setup and adjustment
